This has tangible effects in governance, for instance, the @urbaninstitute has found that only fifteen states reported Hispanic ethnicity in their arrest records (California is not one of the 15).
Source and #dataviz : https://t.co/PQblxTfVZe

While the United States population is 17.4% Hispanic, Hispanics are greatly underrepresented in governance & policy. Even in Cali, where 38.6% of the population is Hispanic, this population controls between 12% and 24% of state and local political bodies: https://t.co/RpOMikTgAO

You can stay engaged and politically active, but take it easy on the politics horserace. Deepen your policy knowledge instead. It'll last longer, feel better, and build to better political context anyway. https://t.co/kPPLZg8lYV

I'm already a big fan of @voxdotcom's The Weeds podcast, which I strongly recommend. So. I'm really excited to see the @urbaninstitute get into the podcast game - a rare opportunity to hear directly from expert policy researchers in an easy to consume way
https://t.co/Twdo95SHjm

I listen to a lot of politics podcasts, honestly, too many. A lot of the information is fleeting, the topics ephemeral, and the sportsmanship harmful.
One thing I'm gonna do in 2018: less politics, more policy.

@TheLBJSchool Taking a shot here, but if I were looking for someone at the LBJ School who is interested in data / data science / computer science, as well as public policy, who might that be? Or alternatively, is there a better way to ask this question other than on the twitters.
@ThatSSR You know I have to imagine it's taken, but I never checked.
